author: Cynthia Payne

review: So I heard this was great. It allowed all the content on your computer to be broadcast on your TV. What I found out was that it allows you to broadcast all the content of your phone to your TV, as everyone in the room gets to see whatever you're looking at on the screen of your phone as you do so. Meaning you don't select what to share, and embarrassing or private content may be shown to a room of strangers. What's more, if you want to share anything from your computer, it has to be uploaded to your Google+ account. Not exactly broadcasting the contents of your computer.As for all the other apps you can now use on your TV, like Netflix or YouTube, yeah, you can do that with Chrome. For some reason if you don't have a Playstation, Wii, or  other device that was already doing all the streaming content apps, then Chrome is really great. However I already have a PS3 that can do all of this and more, so Chrome is like a sad latecomer, with half the bag of tricks.Unlike a simple USB wifi device, Chrome also requires a plug-in power source, so it's not something that I would consider mobile.So if you don't have a way to watch Netflix on your TV yet, get a chrome, otherwise, ignore the hype, it's not worth it.
